sets.name: Sheer Force
sets.description: Sheer Force + Life Orb Gengar is a fantastic wallbreaker that boasts great coverage, power, Speed, and the ability to switch moves on the fly. Focus Blast nails the few threats that comfortably stomach Shadow Ball, such as Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Nasty Plot provides the power necessary to clean opposing teams and works well with the switches Gengar forces, while Will-O-Wisp cripples some of its few reliable switch-ins like RegenVest Tinkaton. Sludge Bomb is Gengar's single most powerful attack, but Energy Ball is an option to safely OHKO Great Tusk and threaten Garganacl and Ting-Lu without risking a Focus Blast miss; Thunderbolt is a final option to target Corviknight, Toxapex, and Bulletproof Gholdengo. Gengar appreciates slow pivoting support from the likes of Corviknight and works well with fast teammates like Greninja and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks that take advantage of weakened walls. Gengar is exceedingly frail and vulnerable to common priority and Choice Scarf users, so teammates like Regenerator Great Tusk and Roaring Moon are highly advised; the latter also offers counterplay to the occasional Bulletproof user, like Gholdengo.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance + Extreme Speed Aerilate Dragonite serves as a powerful offensive threat that can check sweepers like Chien-Pao. Earthquake hits non-Earth Eater Gholdengo and Sand Stream Garganacl, Fire Blast breaks through Fluffy Corviknight, and Ice Beam deals with Hippowdown, Garchomp, and Altaria. Heavy-Duty Boots affords the most longevity, whereas Sharp Beak and Life Orb are better suited for hyper offense teams. Dragonite does tend to struggle to break through bulky Fluffy and Intimidate walls, so it appreciates powerful wallbreakers like Sheer Force Gengar; in return, Dragonite can use Extreme Speed to cover faster offensive threats. Dragonite also appreciates teammates like Corviknight, which can provide Defog support for non-Heavy Duty Boots variants and defensively handle anti-priority users like Queenly Majesty Polteageist.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Aerilate Dragonite serves as a potent offensive cleaner and revenge killer, capitalizing on its priority -ate Speed to threaten fast offensive Pokemon like Barraskewda and Chien-Pao. If forgoing recovery, Thunder Punch can help break through Corviknight. For the 4th moveslot, Earthquake is generally best to hit foes like non-Earth Eater Gholdengo and Kingambit, while Fire Blast is an option to break Fluffy Corviknight and Tera Blast chips neutral Fur Coat users like Hippowdown. This set appreciates Rapid Spin and Defog support from the likes of Corviknight and Iron Treads, respectively, which can also pivot Dragonite into offensive threats it normally couldn't switch into. Dragonite pairs up well with wallbreakers like Sheer Force Gengar to help break through physical walls; in return, Dragonite threatens fast offensive threats with Extreme Speed.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: With Ice Scales, Blissey is a titanic special wall that checks prominent attackers like Gholdengo and Iron Bundle; Good as Gold is an alternative to stop Taunt users like Chi-Yu, which otherwise take advantage of Blissey. Thunder Wave lets Blissey cripple foes such as Corviknight and Kingambit, which could otherwise switch into it free of charge, while Calm Mind helps Blissey keep up with foes like Nasty Plot Gholdengo, ensuring they do not break past it. Shadow Ball lets Blissey hit Ghost-types like Dragapult and Gholdengo, denying them setup opportunities. Heavy-Duty Boots is preferred to avoid entry hazard chip damage from repeated switch-ins, but Leftovers provides passive recovery. Physically defensive teammates like Fur Coat Avalugg and Flogres help cover the physical attackers that threaten Blissey, like Aerilate Dragonite and Dragon Rush Dragapult. Slow but powerful wallbreakers such as Slither Wing and Ceruledge appreciate Blissey paralyzing offensive foes, giving them more chances to wallbreak.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description: With good natural bulk, a great typing, phazing, and both Spikes and Stealth Rock, Garchomp is an effective entry hazard setter that also checks common threats like Orichalcum Pulse Ceruledge. Swords Dance is an option over either entry hazard to pressure bulkier teams. Dragon Tail forces switches and potentially create a favorable situation for Garchomp and helps rack up even more entry hazard damage. As Garchomp does not have any reliable recovery, Leftovers is the preferred option to give Garchomp longevity, but Heavy-Duty Boots is great for opposing hazard-stack matchups. Due to Garchomp mainly being an entry hazard setter, it greatly appreciates teammates such as Good as Gold Skeledirge to keep the entry hazards up in the face of Defog and Rapid Spin. Garchomp also works well with offensive threats such as Sheer Force Gengar, as the entry hazards can wear down its checks into KO range. Garchomp struggles to check common attackers like Noivern and Greninja, so secondary checks like physically defensive Clodsire are appreciated.

sets.name: Fur Coat
sets.description: Fluffy Hippowdon is a remarkable physical wall thanks to its defensive stats, reliable recovery in Slack Off, and pure Ground typing, letting it check non-Mold Breaker offensive threats like Dragonite, Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing. Whirlwind prevents foes like the aforementioned Dragonite from setting up. Rocky Helmet punishes the physical attackers it checks and lets it pseudo-spinblock Great Tusk, Cyclizar, and Iron Treads; alternatively, Leftovers gives it extra recovery without having to waste Slack Off PP. 25 Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight, allowing it to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Specially defensive walls like Corviknight, Florges, and Blissey can compensate for Hippowdon's poor Special Defense and check foes like Chi-Yu and Greninja. In return, they appreciate Hippowdon dealing with Ceruledge, Kingambit, and Slither Wing.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Volcarona's great defensive typing and solid bulk makes it a good defensive pivot for threats such as non-Stakeout Iron Valiant and Slither Wing while checking Iron Bundle and Quaquaval with Desolate Land. Morning Sun gives Volcarona a boosted recovery under Desolate Land, and Will-O-Wisp enables Volcarona to cripple its switch-ins. The 32 Speed EVs allow Volcarona to outpace and burn uninvested Garchomp with Will-O-Wisp. Specially defensive walls like Ice Scales Corviknight appreciate Volcarona's ability to switch into to mixed threats like Iron Valiant. Specially offensive Ghosts like Dragapult and Gholdengo also appreciate Volcarona's ability to spread burns and allow them to utilize Hex at full power. Heavy-Duty Boots is vital for Volcarona's longevity, so it is recommended to pair Volcarona with a Knock Off switchin like Great Tusk or Iron Hands to mitigate the chance of being vulnerable to entry hazards.

sets.name: Fast Support
sets.description: Volcarona is a solid support pokemon that can potentially sweep with Quiver Dance. Fiery Dance lets Volcarona increase its Special Attack without having to setup, while Flamethrower has more PP and immediate power. Will-O-Wisp cripples switch-ins like Dragonite and is generally great for weakening physical attackers like Great Tusk. Teammates such as Baxcalibur and Roaring Moon appreciate Volcarona's ability to sponge priority moves from Slither Wing and Hatterene. Bulky Ground-types like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk also benefit from Volcarona ability to somewhat safely switch into offensive Water-types such as Greninja and Quaquaval. Volcarona is walled by common Well-Baked Body users like Gholdengo and Corviknight, so attackers like Great Tusk and Baxcalibur are helpful for breaking through them. Volcarona can also have trouble getting past Fire-resistant specially defensive walls that resist fire like Roaring Moon and Garganacl, so a physical wallbreaker such as Slither Wing is recommended.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Primordial Sea Greninja can use its rain-boosted attacks to wallbreak with Choice Specs or serve as a valuable revenge killer and late-game cleaner with Choice Scarf, outspeeding boosted threats such as Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks, Surge Surfer Houndstone, and +1 Volcarona. Choice Specs-boosted Hydro Pump's higher power 2HKOes even Water-resistant foes such as Baxcalibur, Dondozo, and Quaquaval. U-turn lets it act as a solid offensive pivot, pairing extremely well with other offensive teammates like Great Tusk and Armarouge that threaten its switch-in such as Toxapex, Desolate Land Iron Moth, and Roaring Moon. Greninja can run an entry hazard of choice since it forces multiple switches and threatens common hazard removers like Great Tusk and Corviknight, whittling down its checks in the long run. Switcheroo immediately cripples its defensive checks as well as bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Scream Tail and Florges, especially for Choice Scarf variants that can't immediately harm them. Water Shuriken is a fringe option that can pick off weakened foes like Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Noivern. VoltTurn support from Pokemon such as Cinderace and Iron Moth is appreciated to bring Greninja in safely on foes like Great Tusk and Garganacl.

sets.name: Magic Guard + Life Orb
sets.description: With high Speed that allows it to outspeed most of the unboosted metagame and Life Orb-boosted Special Attack, Greninja is a powerful special threat that uses its fantastic STAB combination to 2HKO common metagame threats like Gholdengo, Great Tusk, and Garganacl. Water Shuriken allows Greninja to reliably revenge kill weakened opponents and break through Substitute, while Ice Beam gives coverage against Pokemon like Roaring Moon and Garchomp. Greninja struggles against special walls like Florges and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, so physically offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk and Dragonite that can threaten them are good teammates. Due to its defensive frailty, Greninja also appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Cinderace that can safely pivot it in. Thanks to its immunity to entry hazards, Greninja fits well on offensive entry hazard stacking teams with little or no entry hazard removers.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Florges's extremely high Special Defense stat makes it an effective wall that also provides utility in the form of Wishpassing. With Unaware, Florges is able to comfortably set up on and check Pokemon such as Quiver Dance Volcarona, Fiery Dance Iron Moth, and Hatterene. Tablets of Ruin is also a viable option that allows Florges to easily switch into and threaten Pokemon such as Great Tusk. Calm Mind + Wish and Synthesis give Florges the longevity necessary to serve a bulky sweeper. Wish + Protect provides guaranteed healing and can be used to scout options from foes; it also synergizes well with chip damage from other sources, like Garganacl's Salt Cure and poison damage from Toxic Spikes. Despite its nturally high Special Defense, Florges is threatened by special attackers that can muscle through it,such as Sheer Force Gengar and almost all variants of Gholdengo. Florges thus appreciates teammates that can handle these threats such as RegenVest Roaring Moon and Bulletproof Gholdengo. To compensate for its relatively low physical bulk, Florges can be paired with teammates who are more physically defensive, such as Dondozo, Corviknight, and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Ice Scales
sets.description: Ice Scales Toxapex utilizes its remarkable special bulk and valuable defensive typing to check offensive threats such as Chi-Yu, Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and non-Mold Breaker Iron Bundle. The combination of Toxic + Haze lets Toxapex shut down and eventually beat setup sweepers that try to overwhelm it such as Dragonite, Ceruledge, and Volcarona. Liquidation pressures Toxic-immune foes like Clodsire and Kingambit. Toxic Spikes is an option to spread status more easily, which works well with Hex users such as Gholdengo and Dragapult. Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Hippowdon can check threatening foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands for it; Corviknight's Defog also relieves entry hazard pressure from Toxapex if not running Heavy-Duty Boots, while Hippowdon's Stealth Rock works well with Toxapex's poison to spread further passive damage.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Cinderace is a potent wallbreaker that can OHKO or 2HKO common defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Kingambit. While Mold Breaker beats Well-Baked Body users like Corviknight and Gholdengo, Desolate Land allows Cinderace to 2HKO even Fire-resistant Pokemon like Dragonite with Pyro Ball. Gunk Shot is a good option to hit Fairy-types like Scream Tail and Florges, while Sucker Punch allows Cinderace to revenge kill weakened opponents, namely Houndstone. Cinderace struggles against Primordial Sea users like Barraskewda and certain physical walls like Dondozo, so it appreciates teammates like Rotom-W that can threaten these Pokemon. Due to its low defensive stats and weakness to entry hazards, Cinderace appreciates pivoting and entry hazard removal from teammates like Corviknight and Great Tusk. Cinderace also pairs well with offensive pivots like Greninja, as they can easily maneuver around and threaten each other's checks.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: With high Defense and a good defensive typing, Corviknight is a reliable physical wall that can switch into offensive threats like Kingambit and Great Tusk, as well as remove entry hazards without being threatened by entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu and Clodsire. Well-Baked Body allows Corviknight to fearlessly switch into Fire-type attacks from Pokemon like Cinderace and Iron Moth, Intimidate and Fluffy make Corviknight a good switch into physical attackers like Quaquaval and Aerilate Dragonite, and Delta Stream alongside Body Press helps Corviknight to better counter Baxcalibur. Brave Bird lets Corviknight threaten Pokemon like Great Tusk and Meowscarada, Body Press beats Kingambit and Baxcalibur, and Iron Head can be used to threaten Baxcalibur and Chien-Pao while still hitting Ghost-types. Corviknight also acts as a slow pivot with U-turn, allowing it to bring in offensive teammates like Dragonite and Baxcalibur safely. Corviknight struggles to hurt Steel-type Pokemon like Gholdengo and Iron Treads, so it appreciates teammates like Chi-Yu and Great Tusk that can take them out. Due to its middling Special Defense, Corviknight also appreciates teammates like Garganacl and Florges that can take special attacks.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Corviknight makes use of its good defensive typing and decent special bulk to serve as both a special pivot and a Defogger that doesn't fear common entry hazard setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu. Well-Baked Body is great for checking Volcarona and Iron Moth, and Volt Absorb allows Corviknight to block Volt Switch from Pokemon like Rotom-Wash and Sandy Shocks. Brave Bird can be used to hit Great Tusk, while Iron Head threatens Ice-types like Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur. U-turn and minimum Speed turn Corviknight into a slow pivot, allowing it to safely bring in frail Pokemon like Gengar and Ceruledge. Corviknight has difficulty against physical walls like Dondozo and Kingambit, so teammates like Sandy Shocks and Iron Moth that can handle them are necessary. Because Corviknight can't run multiple immunity abilities, a second specially defensive partner like Garganacl or Clodsire should be used to help cover its defensive weaknesses.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Barraskewda is a devastating wallbreaker with a naturally high Speed tier to outpace the whole unboosted metagame, including fast threats like Chien-Pao and Kilowattrel. Close Combat pressures Baxcalibur, Roaring Moon, and Desolate Land Chi-Yu and provides strong neutral coverage for Dondozo and Desolate Land Cinderace. Psychic Fangs and Drill Run cover foes such as Toxapex, Water Absorb Gengar, and Iron Moth; the latter's lesser power and accuracy is compensated for by hitting Desolate Land Ceruledge and OHKOing Cinderace. Aqua Jet revenge kills faster foes like boosted Volcarona and Choice Scarf Chi-Yu and Sandy Shocks. Specially offensive pivots such as Iron Moth and Greninja can bring Barraskewda in safely on their switch-ins like Garganacl, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu for more wallbreaking opportunities. Late-game cleaners like Baxcalibur, Dragonite, and Choice Scarf Sandy Shocks love Barraskewda pressuring the opposition early on; Sandy Shocks threatens problematic bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex in return.

sets.name: Shell Smash
sets.description: Polteageist is a dangerous setup sweeper and cleaner thanks to Shell Smash, Stored Power, and its excellent Special Attack, allowing it to sweep with a single turn of setup. Giga Drain provides coverage for Ting-Lu and Garganacl, Strength Sap gives Polteageist a way to restore its Focus Sash after chip damage and set up on weaker physical attackers, while Substitute allows for safe setup on status-reliant walls like Blissey. Focus Sash the preferred item to safely ensure Polteageist can use Shell Smash. Polteageist can often struggle to get itself onto the field safely, so it appreciates a slow pivot from Corviknight or Shed Tail Cyclizar who can also facilitate Polteageist's setup with screens or a passed Substitute. Polteageist pairs well with physical wallbreakers like Swords Dance Cinderace that can break through opposing walls. Due to its reliance on Focus Sash, Polteageist needs reliable entry hazard removal like Cyclizar and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Triage
sets.description: Hatterene is a decent Triage user that can successfully check dangerous attackers like Aerilate Dragonite, Greninja, and most Chien-Pao. Calm Mind and its good bulk allow it to set up and beat bulkier foes as well. Psyshock provides effectively mixed coverage, most notably beating Blissey. For the last moveslot, Mystical Fire beats non-Well-Baked Body Corviknight and Gholdengo, Nuzzle cripples switch-ins like Kingambit, and Giga Drain hits Garganacl hard while providing more recovery and priority. Other sweepers benefit greatly from the dents placed by Hatterene, such as Shell Smash Polteageist and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Dragonite. Hatterene is weak to mainly priority-immune Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and Shell Smash Polteageist. Kingambit, with or without RegenVest, is a reliable check to Polteageist. Great Tusk is a solid partner, as it handles many of Hatterene's checks and also provides entry hazard removal. Hatterene also struggles with Fire-type Pokemon, making teammates like Garchomp and Well-Baked Body Kingambit naturally good partners.

sets.name: Good as Gold
sets.description: Good as Gold Skeledirge's great bulk, typing, and movepool make it a decent deterrent to entry hazard removal and excellent status spreader. Will-O-Wisp + Hex spreads chip damage, neuters physical attackers, and gives Skeledirge the most firepower; Roar + Shadow Ball is a more consistent alternative that deters setup and racks up entry hazard chip. Teammates that can reliably set entry hazards long-term such as Fur Coat or Regenerator Garchomp and Regenerator Ting-Lu are great partners, as they greatly appreciate Skeledirge's ability to deter hazard-removing attempts. Pokemon that check the likes of Greninja and Noivern such as Sand Stream Garganacl and specially defensive Desolate Land Volcarona make for great defensive partners alongside Skeledirge. Strong wallbreakers such as Great Tusk and Cinderace appreciate Skeledirge’s ability to keep entry hazards up by preventing Corviknight's Defog—and potentially risk a spinblock against Great Tusk and Iron Treads—allowing them to further pressure the opposing team. 12 Speed EVs let Skeledirge outspeed and either damage or burn Corviknight.

sets.name: Making Waves (3 Attacks + Roost)
sets.description: Quaquaval provides a decent offensive presence and valuable utility. Its typing in Water / Fighting and Roost allow it to soft check and threaten out foes like Chi-Yu, Roaring Moon, and Iron Moth. It's a solid spinner because it threatens out common entry hazard setters like Great Tusk, Garganacl, and Ting-Lu and spinblockers like Skeledirge and Gholdengo. Aqua Step or Rapid Spin's Speed boost allows it to outspeed would-be revenge killers such as Noivern and Chien-Pao, which lets Quaquaval potentially clean up late-game. Mystic Water + Primordial Sea provides more offensive presence and works well with Aqua Step for a recoil-less Water-type attack, while Magic Guard lets Quaquaval ignore Life Orb and Wave Crash recoil and lets it comfortably switch into entry hazards to make use of Rapid Spin. Rapid Spin variants pair well with hazard-stacking teammates like Garchomp and Ting-Lu; they also help switch into Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Volcarona, and Ceruledge that wall Quaquaval, the latter of which can spinblock it reliably.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Quaquaval is a solid wallbreaker thanks to its high-Base Power STAB moves backed up by a good Attack stat. Primordial Sea amplifies Wave Crash's power to even higher levels, but Sword of Ruin is an option to boost its other attacks, notably 2HKOing defensive Desolate Land Volcarona with Close Combat. Ice Spinner gives it coverage for Dragon-types such as Dragonite. U-turn lets Quaquaval gain momentum, taking advantage of Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Ceruledge and Volcarona. Because of this, Quaquaval pairs well with teammates that can threaten them like Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Dragonite; the former two also provide entry hazards to punish foes trying to switch around Quaquaval, while the latter appreciates Quaquaval wallbreaking early-game for it to sweep easier. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed Slither Wing and neutral-natured Baxcalibur and Great Tusk.

sets.name: Sticky Web Setter
sets.description: Prankster Spidops is the optimal Sticky Web setter for hyper offense teams. Spikes can be used to add more residual damage for opposing switch-ins, while Toxic Spikes synchronizes well with Hex users such as Gholdengo and Gengar. Taunt is used to block setup and Defog, while Circle Throw forces switches and can rack up residual damage in combination with Spikes. Focus Sash is used to ensure that Spidops can get up Sticky Web and at least one layer of Spikes before fainting. Slow wallbreakers like Chi-Yu and Houndstone appreciate the opportunities provided by Sticky Web support. Setup attackers such as Baxcalibur, Chien-Pao, and Ceruledge also pair well with Spidops, as it enables them to outspeed would-be revenge killers. Spidops struggles to set Sticky Web against spinners, so it's recommended to pair Spidops with a Ghost-type like Earth Eater Gholdengo that can beat antileads like Great Tusk. Additionally, common Dark-types like Kingambit and Roaring Moon can set up on Spidops lacking Circle Throw, so pairing it with a strong Fighting type like Slither Wing is advised.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Garganacl is an incredibly reliable special wall and premier Noivern counter. Sand Stream offers higher walling capabilities and forces extra chip damage on opponents, and it can reduce Orichalcum Pulse Cinderace's damage output in a pinch; alternatively, Vessel of Ruin works regardless of the weather. Stealth Rock supports its team with additional chip damage, and Protect can both scout opposing Choice-locked attackers and rack up Salt Cure damage; alternatively, IronPress threatens instant damage on foes, as well as boosts its Defense to better handle physical attackers like Great Tusk. Earthquake hits opposing Garganacl and can prevent Covert Cloak Gholdengo from using Garganacl as setup fodder. Garganacl's best fit is on balance teams that want a reliable special wall and entry hazard support. Teammates like Earth Eater Gholdengo and Rocky Helmet Corviknight are recommended to prevent Regenerator Great Tusk from freely switching in and using Rapid Spin. Garganacl struggles to deal with Greninja and Gengar, as both can OHKO it, so a teammate like Desolate Land Iron Moth helps cover these weaknesses.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Garganacl serves as a solid physically defensive Pokemon that checks threats such as Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and Cinderace with its natural bulk and typing. Levitate notably prevents Garganacl from being worn down by Spikes and Toxic Spikes, but Earth Eater is an option on teams with reliable entry hazard control. Good as Gold can also be used to provide more defensive utility against common status moves, such as Trick from Choice item Gholdengo and Defog from Corviknight, denying them and seizing momentum. Salt Cure chips switch-ins like Corviknight and Great Tusk. The listed setup and coverage moves enable Garganacl to accomplish feats like winning the one-on-one against Great Tusk and Kingambit with Curse or IronPress, racking up chip damage with Salt Cure + Protect, and hitting Magic Guard Gholdengo with Earthquake on the switch-in. Garganacl benefits from teammates such as Desolate Land Volcarona and Iron Moth, which check Water-type threats such as Quaquaval and Greninja. It's also recommended to pair Garganacl with Pokemon that can account for Rapid Spin users such as Great Tusk, so teammates like Earth Eater Gholdengo and Brambleghast are great choices.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Armarouge is a passable revenge killer that outspeeds naturally fast Pokemon like Cinderace, Noivern, and Chien-Pao, threatening them with its high-Base Power STAB attacks. Moreover, it can clean up late-game easily thanks to Psychic Surge, which protects it from common priority attacks such as Dragonite's Extreme Speed, Slither Wing's First Impression, and Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Trick cripples bulky foes it can't immediately threaten like Blissey, Florges, and Garganacl. Focus Blast hits Chi-Yu and Roaring Moon, while Psyshock 2HKOes Clodsire. Utility moves in Destiny Bond and Will-O-Wisp can also be used, with the former checking setup sweepers like Baxcalibur and Dragonite and the latter punishing switch-ins. Wallbreakers like Greninja can overwhelm shared checks and appreciate Armarouge's Psychic Terrain protecting them from the likes of Ceruledge's Shadow Sneak and Dragonite's Extreme Speed. Armarouge's susceptibility to entry hazards makes teammates like Defog Corviknight and Rapid Spin Great Tusk valuable options.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Ceruledge is an incredibly powerful wallbreaker due to its potent offensive typing, boosted Fire-type attacks, and stellar coverage. Shadow Sneak makes up for Ceruledge's lackluster Speed and can finish off faster Pokemon. Solar Blade and Close Combat provide coverage against foes that tank Ceruledge's STAB moves, such as Garganacl, Great Tusk, Chi-Yu, and Roaring Moon. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp gives up coverage for the ability to cripple switch-ins like Garchomp and Hippowdon. Orichalcum Pulse is the preferred ability due to the Attack bonus, but Desolate Land provides it with some defensive utility by checking opposing Primordial Sea users. Due to Ceruledge's frailty, it appreciates pivoting and entry hazard removal from teammates like Corviknight, Great Tusk, and Iron Treads. Strong special attackers such as Greninja can pair with Ceruledge to break down each other's checks, such as Garganacl and Garchomp and Blissey and Corviknight, respectively.

sets.name: Choiced Attacker
sets.description: Ceruledge's sun-boosted Bitter Blade offers a combination of power and longevity scarcely seen in a wallbreaker. Choice Band Bitter Blade 2HKOes the majority of the metagame, while Choice Scarf Ceruledge outpaces Chien-Pao and Cinderace. Close Combat hits Garganacl and Well-Baked Body Steel-types, and Solar Blade hits Great Tusk. Will-O-Wisp cripples many of Ceruledge's switch-ins, such as Garganacl. On Choice Band sets, a Jolly Nature is useful for outpacing opposing Ceruledge and Gholdengo. The additional power offered by Orichalcum Pulse is significant, but Desolate Land can be used to offensively check Barraskewda. Ceruledge's Stealth Rock weakness and lackluster bulk make Defog and pivot support from a teammate like Corviknight very valuable. Great Tusk's offensive presence and Knock Off support greatly complements Ceruledge's own offensive prowess and burn spreading capabilities; defensive cores can quickly crumble under the weight of entry hazards, burn chip, and repeated subjection to Bitter Blade and Headlong Rush. Fast special attackers like Greninja and Noivern help deal with faster threats and Garganacl.

sets.name: Primordial Sea
sets.description: Primordial Sea Kilowattrel is a powerful threat with excellent Speed, strong weather-boosted moves, great coverage, and pivoting. Naturally outspeeding most common threats except Chien-Pao and Barraskewda, Kilowattrel can safely pivot or threaten massive damage against the entire tier. Choice Specs 2HKOes fully invested Ting-Lu and Clodsdire with Weather Ball. U-turn provides safe pivoting with no immunities, while Volt Switch is significantly stronger and provides important coverage if forgoing Thunder. Kilowattrel excels in VoltTurn cores, while also acting as a sweeper in the right scenarios, making other pivots such as Roaring Moon and Cinderace excellent partners. Powerful cleaners like Choice Band Dragonite appreciate Kilowattrel breaking their common Steel-type switch-ins, and setup attackers mesh well with Kilowattrel’s ability to OHKO Great Tusk and Corviknight. Kilowattrel is extremely weak to Chien-Pao and common priority users like Baxcalibur, making sturdy physical walls like Delta Stream Corviknight great partners. Defensive pivots like Corviknight and Great Tusk also provide much needed Stealth Rock removal, if running Choice Specs.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Tinkaton's decent bulk with Assault Vest and incredible defensive typing allow it to pivot into and check special attackers such as Noivern and Gengar. Knock Off is Tinkaton's most important move, as it hits Gholdengo and removes crucial items from common switch-ins such as Corviknight, Skeledirge, and Iron Treads. Skitter Smack lowers the Special Attack of bulky Calm Mind users such as Florges and powerful wallbreakers such as Chi-Yu, allowing Tinkaton and its teammates to more easily handle these threats. Play Rough and Ice Hammer both hit Dragon-types such as Roaring Moon hard; Play Rough also dents Fighting-types such as Slither Wing while Ice Hammer deals huge damage to Garchomp, Dragonite, and Clodsire. Physically defensive walls such as Hippowdon can deal with the physical wallbreakers that threaten Tinkaton, like Ceruledge and Great Tusk, and appreciate it relieving pressure against Greninja. Slower attackers such as Great Tusk, Baxcalibur, and Quaquaval benefit from Tinkaton handling fast revenge killers such as Noivern and Gengar for them.

sets.name: Shed Tail
sets.description: Shed Tail, Regenerator, and good Speed give Cyclizar a unique role on offensive teams: safely bringing in powerful attackers like Cinderace, Noivern, and Dragonite multiple times per battle. Draco Meteor KOes opposing Cyclizar and picks off weakened foes. U-turn lets Cyclizar pivot out without self-damage, healing from Regenerator to potentially use Shed Tail again later. Rapid Spin and/or Knock Off provide further utility. Choice Scarf + Shed Tail is preferred against Chien-Pao and other fast threats, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to avoid entry hazard damage and the Choice lock. Cyclizar benefits greatly from a strong physical wall or Dazzling user to deal with priority attackers like Dragonite; strong attackers like Cinderace and Noivern are valuable for dealing with phazers like Hippowdon, or a Good as Gold user like Skeledirge or Gholdengo can block phazing moves outright.

sets.name: Surge Surfer
sets.description: Choice Band Houndstone makes use of STAB Last Respects's absurd late-game power and Surge Surfer's Speed boost to become a terrifying cleaner, capable of denting even Ghost-resistant Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Roaring Moon. Under Electric Terrain, Houndstone outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, as well as boosted foes such as Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. Shadow Sneak picks off faster threats like boosted Volcarona and is especially useful if Electric Terrain is not active. Alternatively, Will-O-Wisp cripples bulky Pokemon such as Blissey and Great Tusk and punishes Sucker Punch attempts from Kingambit and Chien-Pao. Play Rough threatens Dark-types early-game and hits Normal-types like Cyclizar. Trick cripples walls and bulky setup sweepers such as Blissey, Dondozo, and Garganacl and is useful in matchups where Houndstone will not be able to sweep. Hadron Engine users like Sandy Shocks and Gengar are necessary to activate Surge Surfer; the former can also pivot Houndstone in safely via Volt Switch. Offensive teammates like Great Tusk, Cinderace, and Chien-Pao can soften up physical walls like Corviknight and Dondozo as well as pressure Dark- and Normal-types such as Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Blissey for Houndstone to have an easier time using Last Respects.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Houndstone takes advantage of its boosted Last Respects to become a remarkable late-game cleaner. Adaptability powers up Last Respects with a consistent boost that is not as teammate-dependent, which makes it the better ability early- to mid-game, while Supreme Overlord offers the best late-game damage. Early-game, Will-O-Wisp cripples walls like Ting-Lu and Blissey and punishes Kingambit attempting to pick Houndstone off with Sucker Punch. Play Rough threatens Dark-types such as Greninja and Chien-Pao while hitting Normal-types like Cyclizar. Trick cripples defensive foes like the aforementioned Blissey and Ting-Lu, which improves its matchup against defensive teams where Choice Scarf's Speed boost is unnecessary. Due to Houndstone's middling Speed tier, it appreciates Sticky Web from teammates like Spidops to slow down faster threats such as Jolly Chien-Pao and other Choice Scarf users. Other hyper offense staples such as Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Chien-Pao can wallbreak early-game by overwhelming common physical walls like Dondozo and Corviknight as well as pressuring Blissey, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit, which give Choice Scarf Houndstone ample opportunities to clean up late-game.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: A pure Water typing, titanic physical bulk, and Tablets of Ruin make Dondozo a nearly impenetrable physical wall that can blanket check common physical attackers including Great Tusk, Roaring Moon, and Chien-Pao. Other options like Unaware can be used to ignore setup sweepers and wallbreakers that attempts to boost past Dondozo, while Magic Guard prevents it from being overwhelmed by entry hazards, Toxic, and Wave Crash recoil. Aside from turning it into a bulky setup sweeper, Curse also lets Dondozo contest with opposing setup from the likes of Dragonite, Baxcalibur, and Kingambit, especially on non-Unaware variants. Earthquake is a necessary coverage move to hit Toxapex and Desolate Land users like Iron Moth, Cinderace, and Ceruledge. Rest + Leftovers provide much needed longevity, with Rest preventing Dondozo from being permanently crippled by Clodsire's Toxic, Iron Moth's Toxic Spikes, and Volcarona and Skeledirge's Will-O-Wisp. Special walls such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, Garganacl, and Corviknight are necessary to deal with special attackers like Gengar, Sandy Shocks, Chi-Yu, and Noivern, respectively; the former three spread further passive damage onto foes between entry hazards, Toxic, Ruination, and Salt Cure, slowly whittling down foes for Dondozo to sweep easier, while the latter can check Meowscarada and provides Defog to relieve non-Magic Guard Dondozo from entry hazard damage that would otherwise force it to use Rest more frequently. In return, Dondozo covers the likes of Great Tusk, Quaquaval, and Cinderace for them.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: A unique defensive typing, reliable recovery, and remarkable special bulk enhanced by Vessel of Ruin allow Clodsire to check prominent special attackers like Iron Moth, Noivern, Gengar, and non-Earth Eater Gholdengo. Toxic can cripple non-grounded Pokemon such as Noivern and Dragonite as well as Heavy-Duty Boots users like Volcarona and Scream Tail. Toxic Spikes and Poison Jab are better on Prankster sets to punish Dark-types such as Meowscarada, Roaring Moon, and Ting-Lu; in particular, Toxic Spikes lets Clodsire match up well against hyper offense teams filled with setup sweepers. Prankster + Haze allows Clodsire to shut down setup sweepers, like Volcarona and Polteageist, while they whittle down from poison damage. Pokemon like Garganacl and Scream Tail form a hazard-stacking core with Clodsire, and Good as Gold spinblockers like Skeledirge make great teammates as well. Physical walls like the aforementioned Pokemon, Corviknight, and Dondozo handle physical threats such as Baxcalibur, Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Earth Eater Kingambit that can exploit Clodsire's poor physical bulk.

sets.name: Type Immunity
sets.description: Kingambit's good bulk and excellent typing allow it to check dangerous attackers like Gholdengo, Polteageist, and, with the correct ability, Volcarona and defensive Great Tusk. While every team appreciates Stealth Rock, Kingambit can use Swords Dance + Sucker Punch to pressure offensive and defensive checks alike. Alternatively, Kingambit can shut down Toxapex, Dondozo, and Ting-Lu with Taunt. Well-Baked Body counters Iron Moth and non-Mold Breaker Chi-Yu, while Earth Eater checks Iron Treads, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu. 140 Speed EVs outspeeds uninvested Corviknight. Spinners like Great Tusk and priority-fearing setup sweepers like Baxcalibur and Quaquaval gladly let Kingambit take on any Ghost-types or Triage Hatterene blocking their way to victory. Of the same token, Kingambit loves having Ghost-types like Gholdengho or reliable Fighting-type switch-ins like Great Tusk on its team; Kingambit also always appreciates a Water-type or Primordial Sea user if running Earth Eater and Corviknight if running Well-Baked Body.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Kingambit is a dangerous wallbreaker, owing to great base stats and Adaptability. After using Swords Dance, Kingambit threatens the entire tier, including incredibly bulky physical walls such as Fluffy Corviknight and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster threats, such as Cinderance and Noivern, making it difficult to check offensively. Life Orb provides the highest damage boost to Kingambit's attacks; alternatively, Black Glasses provides a damage boost without digging into Kingambit's limited healthpool, while Leftovers allows Kingambit to reliably switch in on weaker attacks. Kingambit best fits on offense teams, which appreciate its massive damage output and can provide opportunities for it to switch in safely. Slow pivoting teammates, such as RegenVest Iron Treads and Corviknight, are recommended, as they can safely pivot Kingambit in and also clear entry hazards. 144 Speed EVs are used to outspeed uninvested Corviknight. Kingambit is incredibly threatened by Great Tusk, as it can easily live even boosted hits and threaten to OHKO back, so teammates like Florges and Noivern are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description: Rapid Spin, Knock Off, and great physical bulk make Great Tusk a fantastic utility spinner. It can check dangerous physical attackers such as Ceruledge, Slither Wing, Kingambit, and Roaring Moon and retaliate with its beefy Earthquake and Body Press. It matches up well against common entry hazard setters like Garganacl and Clodsire, and it threatens spinblockers with Knock Off; Knock Off also augments its teammates' entry hazards by removing Heavy-Duty Boots. Leftovers gives it much needed recovery—especially alongside Regenerator—but Heavy-Duty Boots prevents it from being overwhelmed by the entry hazards it must remove. Teammates such as Blissey and Slowking can cover opposing special attackers that target Great Tusk's lower Special Defense. In return, they appreciate Great Tusk dealing with physical attackers like opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Choice Band Great Tusk is a dangerous wallbreaker thanks to its high-powered STAB moves and either Mold Breaker to bypass Fur Coat or Stakeout for the reliable power against non-Fur Coat targets. Knock Off has no immunities, unlike both STAB options, and removes key items like Leftovers from Corviknight. Ice Spinner breaks through defensive Dragonite and Garchomp with a clean OHKO. Fast specially offensive pivots like Iron Bundle, Dragapult, and Noivern can bring Great Tusk in safely to pressure their specially defensive switch-ins like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Blissey. Defensive pivots such as Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Hands are also good options, as they can switch into faster threats like Iron Bundle and Iron Moth, respectively, which force Great Tusk out. Dragonite and Ceruledge appreciate Great Tusk wallbreaking early-game by threatening Fur Coat users like Corviknight and Garganacl, which lets them clean up late-game more easily.

sets.name: Pixilate
sets.description: Pixilate Boomburst Scream Tail functions as a bulky utility option and a potentially powerful setup threat. With Boomburst, Scream Tail can topple many threats such as Dragonite, Great Tusk, and Roaring Moon, making it far less passive than most walls. Calm Mind lets it serve as a bulky wincon, while Flamethrower deters Steel-types like Gholdengo from switching in and Stealth Rock lets it make progress against foes it cannot threaten like Ice Scales Clodsire. Scream Tail's great matchup into common Dark-, Fighting-, and Dragon-types makes it a great partner for offensive teammates that struggle with those foes, like Iron Bundle, Garchomp, and Iron Treads. Scream Tail struggles with Poison- and Fire-types such as Clodsire and Volcarona, as well as Steel-types if it does not run Flamethrower, so teammates such as Iron Bundle and Iron Treads are appreciated.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Defensive Scream Tail serves as an answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types such as Iron Hands and Dragonite. Encore locks Pokemon into moves that they do not want to be locked into, such as Volcarona with Quiver Dance or Morning Sun, Blissey into Soft-Boiled, and Avalugg into Recover. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be ran if the team needs entry hazard support. Fur Coat is the most common ability, but Regenerator allows it to better check opposing pivots like Iron Hands; alternatively, Prankster Encore can be used to deter opposing setup attempts. Scream Tail serves as a defensive answer to Fighting- and Dragon-types, so Pokemon such as Blissey and Kingambit are appreciated. It is unable to check several common physical attackers like Ceruledge and Kingambit, so secondary physically defensive teammates like Regenerator Iron Hands are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Slither Wing’s massive Attack stat combined with STAB U-turn and First Impression allow it to be a great wallbreaker, revenge killer, and offensive pivot. Earthquake is an option to bash Skeledirge whereas Flare Blitz is better into Corviknight and bulky Fighting resistant foes such as Scream Tail on non-Tinted Lens sets. Tinted Lens is useful for revenge killing Dragonite, and Volcarona with First Impression after minimal chip, Sword of Ruin provides the most power against neutral targets, and Oricalchum Pulse is recommended for Flare Blitz variants. Special wallbreaker partners such as Noivern and Gengar break physical walls that trouble Slither Wing and appreciate Slither Wings's ability to break their checks in return. Slither Wing loves being partnered with bulky pivots such as Chilly Reception Slowking, Corviknight, and Desolate Land Volcarona to get it in safely against the opposing team and start punching holes in defensive cores. Slither Wing tends to invite in Fire-types onto the field, so fire resistant teammates such as Garchomp and Garganacl are appreciated.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Good natural bulk, useful defensive typing, and an excellent support movepool make Slither Wing a good mixed defense pivot that repeatedly pivots and most notably switches into Ground-types like Great Tusk. Regenerator makes the most of its pivoting ability, but Unaware is an option for deterring setup. Will-O-Wisp allows it to punish switch-ins like Garchomp with a burn. Its massive Attack allows it to use STAB U-turn to maintain momentum while bringing in more offensive teammates like Chi-Yu and Greninja. Even with investment, Slither Wing struggles to check certain physical attackers like Ceruledge and Dragonite, so Pokemon like Garganacl and Corviknight make good teammates. Slither Wing also has difficulty against Fairy- and Flying-types like Scream Tail and Noivern, so it appreciates teammates like Iron Moth and Garganacl that are able to handle them.

sets.name: Hadron Engine
sets.description: Hadron Engine Sandy Shocks is a powerful attacker with good STAB coverage and utility in Spikes. Choice Scarf outspeeds major threats like Cinderace, Noivern, Choice Scarf Chi-Yu, and +2 Modest Polteageist, while Choice Specs better pressures opposing walls like Corviknight and Iron Treads. Spikes forces progress even when the opponent has a solid answer to Sandy Shocks, such as Ting-Lu. Sandy Shocks pairs well with strong attackers like Noivern and Gengar, as they take advantage of weakened special walls and Gengar can fire off Terrain-boosted Thunderbolts. Sandy Shocks also appreciates Pokemon that can switch into Ground-type attacks, such as Corviknight, which also gives a slow U-turn to bring Sandy Shocks in safely, and Garchomp, which can also help with stacking entry hazards. Entry hazard removal is particularly helpful, as the Pokemon that usually switch into Sandy Shocks, like Ting-Lu, will often use the opportunity to set entry hazards.

sets.name: Regenerator Pivot
sets.description: RegenVest Iron Treads is a great specially defensive pivot and spinner. It is able to switch into prominent special attackers such as Gholdengo and threaten them out. Knock Off removes key items like Heavy-Duty Boots and deters spinblockers from switching in, and Volt Switch has excellent synergy with Regenerator. If its teammates already provide adequate entry hazard control, Iron Head and Ice Spinner are options to target Scream Tail and Dragonite, respectively. A Sassy nature with minimum Speed investment ensures the slowest possible pivot with Volt Switch. Iron Treads appreciates physically defensive teammates like Slowking, which can form a VoltTurn core to bring in powerful-but-frail teammates like Noivern and Cinderace.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth is a powerful special attacker that also provides good defensive utility thanks to Desolate Land and Morning Sun. Its near-unique offensive typing lets it threaten common walls like Corviknight and Scream Tail, especially when boosted by sun. U-turn can be used to maintain momentum against predicted switch-ins like Garchomp and Garganacl, while Toxic Spikes punishes switch-ins with status. Iron Moth complements Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their vulnerability to Primordial Sea Greninja. Pokemon like Kingambit and Dragonite appreciate Iron Moth taking advantage of their Steel-type checks like Corviknight.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Specially defensive Iron Moth uses its solid bulk, good defensive typing, and sun-boosted Morning Sun to consistently check foes like Volcarona and some Gholdengo variants. It's not entirely passive either, as the boosts from Fiery Dance under sun allow it to eventually overwhelm passive foes like Blissey, Scream Tail, and Florges. U-turn lets it gain momentum by pivoting out safely, and Toxic Spikes punishes grounded foes like Garganacl, Ting-Lu, and Iron Hands. Due to its devastating Ground weakness, Ground-immune Pokemon like Corviknight and Dragonite make good pairings with it. Iron Moth works well with wallbreakers like Great Tusk and Iron Bundle, as they appreciate being given free entry to threaten its switch-ins like Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Iron Moth is a great complement to special walls like Corviknight and Clodsire, as it covers their type weaknesses.

sets.name: Technician
sets.description: Technician Baxcalibur is an incredibly dangerous setup sweeper. Icicle Spear has tremendous damage potential, especially since it bypasses Fluffy, and is relatively consistent thanks to Loaded Dice. Ice Shard provides valuable priority that OHKOes most faster offensive threats at +1 such as Roaring Moon, Sandy Shocks, Noivern, and Meowscarada. Earthquake covers bulky Steel- and Fire-types that can withstand Icicle Spear, such as Kingambit and Gholdengo. Baxcalibur's best fit is on balance and offense teams that can weaken or remove physical walls like Intimidate Corviknight and Dondozo. Entry hazard removal, such as Great Tusk or Corviknight, is recommended to help offset Baxcalibur's weakness to Stealth Rock. Great Tusk can help Baxcalibur sweep with Knock Off and Stealth Rock of its own, whereas Corviknight can safely pivot Baxcalibur in via U-turn. On more offensive teams, such as Sticky Web and dual screens hyper offense, teammates like Houndstone and Chien-Pao can help put additional pressure on physical walls.

sets.name: Offensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Offensive Nasty Plot Gholdengo is a powerful wallbreaker with a near-unresisted STAB combination. After Nasty Plot, Shadow Ball + Make It Rain can 2HKO most walls and OHKO almost everything else. Bulletproof checks opposing Ghost-types by blocking Shadow Ball and also blocks Pyro Ball, while Magic Guard notably turns Garganacl into setup fodder and allows Gholdengo to run the powerful Steel Beam. Recover is the preferred move in the last slot, but it can be replaced with Dazzling Gleam, Focus Blast, Psyshock, or Thunderbolt to hit Roaring Moon, Kingambit, Clodsire, and Corviknight, respectively. Substitute can also be used for safer setup opportunities. This set is mainly weak to Blissey in general, as well as the aforementioned Pokemon without the right coverage,; this makes Great Tusk a great partner for Gholdengo, particularly Bulk Up sets. Gholdengo also pairs well with a Fire-type answer, such as Iron Moth, Well-Baked Body Corviknight, or Primordial Sea users.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Chien-Pao is a threatening wallbreaker thanks to its high Speed and decent STAB coverage that hits common physically defensive walls like Gholdengo and Hippowdon. Sucker Punch picks off faster offensive threats such as Barraskewda and common Choice Scarf users; alternatively, Ice Shard is weaker but hits Roaring Moon super effectively. Sacred Sword beats Steel-types like Kingambit and bypasses Garganacl's Defense boosts. Chien-Pao's best fit is on balance teams that can provide it with safe switch-ins and take advantage of the holes it creates. Noivern and Ceruledge are recommended teammates, as both can help Chien-Pao beat the incredibly troublesome Dondozo and Toxapex. Corviknight and Iron Treads are both good teammates thanks to their ability to pivot Chien-Pao in safely, in addition to clearing Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Dazzling
sets.description: Dazzling Chien-Pao boasts high Attack and Speed, which enable it to check common priority users such as Aerilate Dragonite and Triage Hatterene as well as offensive threats like Gholdengo and Meowscarada. Sacred Sword can be used to deal with Kingambit and Garganacl, which can otherwise safely switch into Chien-Pao, while Ice Shard can be used as a priority option for faster threats like Choice Scarf Meowscarada and Dragon Dance Dragonite. Heavy-Duty Boots allows for Chien-Pao to more reliably check its common targets, while Life Orb can be used to wallbreak more effectively. Frail offensive teammates like Gengar and Iron Moth appreciate Chien-Pao's ability to handle priority users that they'd otherwise be susceptible to. Chien-Pao can have a hard time breaking through physically defensive walls like Corviknight and Dondozo, so pairing it with a specially offensive threat that can handle them like Sandy Shocks or Rotom-W is advised. Chien-Pao is also quite frail, so slow pivots like Corviknight and Slowking can bring it onto the field safely.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu's absurd mixed bulk and unusual typing make it a formidable mixed wall, capable of checking several key threats such as Kingambit, Ceruledge, and Iron Moth. Ting-Lu's best entry hazard depends on its team, as it can form a strong hazard-stacking core with Stealth Rock and/or Spikes setters like Garganacl and Glimmora. Ruination spreads consistent damage, especially against Ground-immune foes like Dragonite and Noivern, and forces defensive Pokemon like Corviknight, Hippowdon, and Blissey to waste their recovery PP. Whirlwind forces entry hazard damage onto foes and ensures Ting-Lu isn't setup fodder for threats like Dragonite and Earth Eater Gholdengo. The Speed IVs let it underspeed Corviknight to punish its Roost with Earthquake. Foes like Scream Tail and Focus Blast Gengar can endanger Ting-Lu by targeting its weaknesses, so Corviknight is a good teammates that also provides Defog.

sets.name: RegenVest Wall
sets.description: Ting-Lu's excellent defensive stats and useful typing let it check a plethora of special attackers such as Gengar, Iron Moth and Gholdengo. Throat Chop lets it beat all Boomburst users and Ground-immune Gholdengo. Ruination + Sand Tomb traps and eliminates opposing Ting-Lu and Skeledirge, while also draining recovery PP from Hippowdon and Blissey. Some special attackers like Scream Tail can prove dangerous, so pairing Ting-Lu with Corviknight and Desolate Land Iron Moth are good options. Ting-Lu can switch into weaker physical attackers like Roaring Moon, but it should be used as help for the main physical wall on the team. Ting-Lu is vulnerable to opposing setup sweepers, so teammates like Unaware Corviknight are greatly appreciated. Corviknight can also reduce its weakness to entry hazards.

sets.name: Choice Item Attacker
sets.description: Chi-Yu's strong base stats and excellent STAB coverage make it a flexible offensive threat. Choice Specs provides maximum wallbreaking power, notably allowing it to OHKO Ice Scales Corviknight and physically defensive Ting-Lu with Desolate Land + Overheat, whereas Choice Scarf gives it the Speed to clean late-game and chase out faster threats like Dragapult and Chien-Pao. Desolate Land provides the most damage amplification and comes with an immunity to Water, whereas No Guard enables Chi-Yu to liberally spread burns with Inferno. Psychic is useful coverage to hit Clodsire and Iron Moth super effectively; alternatively, Will-O-Wisp allows Desolate Land sets to reliably spread burn, however Chi-Yu's poor bulk means it can be dangerous to use. Chi-Yu's best fit is on balance and offense teams that appreciate its high damage output, as well as its good matchups against common special walls like Ice Scales Corviknight and RegenVest Iron Treads. Bulky pivots, like the aforementioned Corviknight and Iron Treads, make particularly good Chi-Yu partners because both can clear entry hazards, particularly Stealth Rock.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Thanks to its high Special Attack and decent Speed, Chi-Yu is a potent wallbreaker that makes use of Nasty Plot and its unresisted STAB combination to tear through common walls like Ice Scales Corviknight, Garganacl, and Florges. Chi-Yu generally prefers to run Heavy-Duty Boots to avoid entry hazard damage, but Life Orb can be run on Sheer Force sets for extra power. Chi-Yu also has several Fire-type STAB moves to choose from: Fire Blast is the most powerful, Flamethrower is the most consistent option, and Inferno is used on No Guard sets to punish switch-ins like Garganacl and Ting-Lu with a burn. Chi-Yu does struggle against special walls like Clodsire and Blissey, so physically offensive Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Iron Hands make good teammates. Chi-Yu is also physically frail, so it appreciates teammates like Corviknight and Avalugg that can switch into strong physical attacks and Wish passers like Florges and Scream Tail that can help it stay healthy.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Roaring Moon's Dragon / Dark typing and high special bulk enable it to switch into Gholdengo, Chi-Yu, Iron Moth, and other special attackers, setting it apart from other offensive pivots like Greninja and Iron Moth. Earthquake forces out Ground-weak Pokemon like Iron Moth and Kingambit. Iron Head and Stone Edge target Florges and Noivern, respectively. Roaring Moon fits best on teams in need of a pivot with both longevity and a Speed tier that exceeds the likes of Chien-Pao and Barraskewda. Roaring Moon struggles to break past physically defensive foes like Great Tusk and Iron Hands, so it appreciates having strong special attackers such as Armarouge and Gengar as teammates. Steel-types like Corviknight and physical walls like Great Tusk are great for patching up Roaring Moon's defensive blind spots.

sets.name: RegenVest
sets.description: Roaring Moon serves as a great specially defensive pivot, able to check various prominent special attackers like Gholdengo and Sandy Shocks with its good bulk and defensive typing. Crunch and Earthquake provide great coverage against the likes of Gholdengo and Iron Moth., Rock Slide consistently hits Volcarona while Stone Edge OHKOes fully defensive Volcarona after Stealth Rock, and Dragon Tail can punish setup and rack up entry hazard chip. Frail offensive attackers like Swords Dance Ceruledge and Cinderace appreciate Roaring Moon getting them onto the field safely. Roaring Moon, despite its great bulk, can fail against Fairy-types, especially Triage Hatterene, so partners like Well-Baked Body Gholdengo and specially defensive Corviknight partner well with Roaring Moon. Corviknight can double as much appreciated hazard removal. Roaring Moon also struggles against most physical attackers and appreciates strong physical walls like Intimidate Corviknight and Fluffy Dondozo as partners.
